Do they talk about obstruction of Congress, which could play into the idea that they're not complying with these subpoenas? Do they talk about specific things with Ukraine? That would be the next step. And even though front and center right now is the Intelligence Committee, next would in fact be the Judiciary Committee.

utterances.speaker: CAVUTO
utterances.utterance: All right, thank you very, very much, my friend. We should be hearing as well from the president very soon. He is addressing the Turning Point USA's Black Leadership Summit. It's largely conservative individuals. They're having this three-day conference. You know the drill. He speaks at the White House, commemorates the weekend plans, and then might take questions or might offer his own. He has essentially dared a vote today on impeachment to Nancy Pelosi to sort of see whether she would do so and get those Democrats in particularly vulnerable districts, or at least ones that Donald Trump won, to put them on. So we should be getting that soon, should be hearing from the president soon. Stay with us.

utterances.speaker: QUESTION
utterances.utterance: Did you see Adam Schiff got four Pinocchios by The Post this morning for lying?

utterances.speaker: TRUMP
utterances.utterance: Well, I heard Adam Schiff got four Pinocchios. That's good. He should have gotten them two-and-a-half years ago.

utterances.speaker: CAVUTO
utterances.utterance: All right, the president saying it took a long time coming, The Washington Post fact-checker giving the House Intelligence chair, Adam Schiff, four Pinocchios for his claim that his committee never spoke to the whistle-blower. It turns out that wasn't quite the case. Normally, The Washington Post is doing that whole Pinocchio thing to him. So, obviously, the leader of the free world was happy to see maybe a little bit of fair and balanced out of that paper. The Wall Street Journal, another great paper. And the guy behind it, James Freeman, says that Chairman Schiff's credibility is indeed on the line here. And he's been playing fast and loose with a lot of stuff. Right?

utterances.speaker: JAMES FREEMAN, CONTRIBUTOR
utterances.utterance: Yes, there's really a history here, this series of falsehoods about the whistle-blower and whether his office was in contact. The remarks that Congressman Schiff attributed to the president that were not actually the president's remarks.

utterances.speaker: CAVUTO
utterances.utterance: Remember that, yes. Recounted it, yes.

utterances.speaker: FREEMAN
utterances.utterance: You go back to the characterization of the call before we got the transcript. Not accurate. And then you go back even further. Mr. Schiff spent two years telling us he had more than circumstantial evidence, in other words, direct evidence, of collusion with Russia. He never produced it. People wondered, how can he talk about it? He's on the Intelligence Committee. You're not supposed to be able to even discuss classified information. The answer was, the information didn't exist. That's why he was able to do it. But...

utterances.speaker: CAVUTO
utterances.utterance: He is the front person here for this, that Jerry Nadler, the Judiciary Committee chief, has been sort of sidelined. And everything goes to Schiff now, right?

utterances.speaker: FREEMAN
utterances.utterance: I think that's why it really goes to the credibility of this whole enterprise, because this is not some backbencher. It's not a member of the Squad saying a bizarre comment that the House leadership then has to figure out how to reckon with. This is the person running the impeachment inquiry.

utterances.speaker: CAVUTO
utterances.utterance: Yes.

utterances.speaker: FREEMAN
utterances.utterance: And this series of falsehoods, I think, has to make people wonder, do they really have a case? And if they do, why do they keep -- I don't want -- I don't know if I want to say lying about it, but it is a series of claims that are not true.

utterances.speaker: CAVUTO
utterances.utterance: Well, misstating facts. It's that old Jean Dean thing, in variance with the facts.

utterances.speaker: FREEMAN
utterances.utterance: Right.

utterances.speaker: CAVUTO
utterances.utterance: So, Jim, one of the things the president says, we have the market up 372 points today, and he was talking about the record low unemployment. You have to go back to 1969 for that low, 3.5 percent. That's all on the line if this impeachment line builds. What do you think?

utterances.speaker: FREEMAN
utterances.utterance: It is, especially if it's Warren, who seems to have the momentum. This is -- you would like the president to be judged on the merits one way or the other.

utterances.speaker: CAVUTO
utterances.utterance: Right.

utterances.speaker: FREEMAN
utterances.utterance: But I think it is underlining that the consequences of ejecting him from office could be -- could be significant. I mean, maybe if you want to sort of...

utterances.speaker: CAVUTO
utterances.utterance: And it's the uncertainty around all that, too, that just sort of rattles folks, if it comes to that, which so far, who knows, right?

utterances.speaker: FREEMAN
utterances.utterance: Yes. I don't think he's going to be removed from office, unless voters decide to do it next November.

utterances.speaker: CAVUTO
utterances.utterance: Yes, or it's a drip, drip, drip thing kind of thing. All right, James Freeman, The Wall Street Journal, much, much more, bestselling author. Well, who says there isn't life after leaving the Trump White House? Forget about singing in the rain. Sean Spicer has been dancing up a storm.

utterances.speaker: CAVUTO
utterances.utterance: All right, we have our Gen Hexed kids here. I like to say kids, because everyone here is a kid -- anyway -- compared to me. But earlier today on FOX Business, I had a chance to talk to former White House Press Secretary Sean Spicer, and what got him into this whole "Dancing With the Stars" thing. He's still in it, you know, so you have to still be in it to win it. Anyway, I asked him why he's doing it, what he thinks about being able to laugh at yourself, just have a fun time, which he is. Take a look.

utterances.speaker: SEAN SPICER, FORMER WHITE HOUSE PRESS SECRETARY
utterances.utterance: A few reasons. One is because you live once. And I thought, you know what, let's have some fun. I'm not a good dancer.

utterances.speaker: CAVUTO
utterances.utterance: You're absolutely right, not about the dancing. We only live once, right, right.

utterances.speaker: SPICER
utterances.utterance: You live once. Have some fun in life. It sounded like -- I had been talking about it with the show for a while. It never fit in with the schedule. My businesses are doing well. My partners could take up the slack. And I thought have some fun, number one. Number two, have a show that I could encourage my children, who are pretty young, to watch. And number three is, we have turned this opportunity into a cause. Everything that we're doing, from auctioning off that bright green shirt, to selling campaign paraphernalia on our Web site, SpicerArnold.com, benefits two veterans charities that I'm involved with, the Independence Fund and the Yellow Ribbon Fund. So we have tried to turn this opportunity into something good for those who have truly sacrificed for our nation. And you know what? I'm having a blast doing it.

utterances.speaker: CAVUTO
utterances.utterance: You know, what I always remember about you, Sean -- and I'm not blowing you smoke, but I do mean this -- you have a great sense of humor. You're very effective at laughing at yourself. My dad used to tell me the same thing. Neil, you might as well laugh at yourself, because, trust me, everyone else is.

utterances.speaker: CAVUTO
utterances.utterance: And I think you're embracing that. And I think that's what has grown your appeal on the show week by week. And are you surprised when you survive another week? Are you surprised when you keep it going?

utterances.speaker: SPICER
utterances.utterance: Yes.

utterances.speaker: SPICER
utterances.utterance: And I'm also humbled. And I know this is a silly -- but I will tell you why, because it's not serious, right? It's a dancing show. It's meant to have fun and entertain people. No one -- none of us are trying to be professional dancers. But it's -- it truly is humbling. And when you stop and go, OK, between 8:00 and 10:00 p.m. on Monday nights, someone is taking away time that they could be spending with their kids, getting ready for the next business day, doing laundry, or cleaning the kitchen or whatever, and they're texting 10 times to support myself and Lindsay Arnold, it actually really humbles you to realize that how many people are taking time out of their day to vote for you. And they go -- if you go to SpicerArnold.com, you can actually sign up, and we will send you updates.

utterances.speaker: SPICER
utterances.utterance: But it humbled me. It did humble me a bit to realize, because I thought...

utterances.speaker: CAVUTO
utterances.utterance: I like how you made it a political campaign. You made it a campaign. That was a good move.

utterances.speaker: SPICER
utterances.utterance: Right.

utterances.speaker: CAVUTO
utterances.utterance: I don't mean to sort of throw in politics here. But we live in a very polarizing, eat them up alive world.

utterances.speaker: SPICER
utterances.utterance: Yes.

utterances.speaker: CAVUTO
utterances.utterance: The Democrats going after the president on impeachment, the president going after them for pushing impeachment. It's a nasty time. I almost think juxtaposing that and you on this show is a reminder, maybe we can just chill a little bit, you know?

utterances.speaker: SPICER
utterances.utterance: Well, and it's what you and Joe were talking about a little. Like, here's the thing. What I love about this show is that there's -- we started with 12 people, literally from the most diverse backgrounds. You have got some athletes, some comedians, actresses, singers.

utterances.speaker: CAVUTO
utterances.utterance: Oh, yes.

utterances.speaker: SPICER
utterances.utterance: And none of us talk politics ever. I don't really know where any of them lie. I can probably guess on a few.

utterances.speaker: SPICER
utterances.utterance: But we actually go out there. We root for each other. We actually want each other to do well. We don't take it -- we work hard, but it's not that serious. And for two hours, people can tune into something, and people are enjoying themselves, rooting for each other, having a good time. And then you can go back to whatever you have been doing in the past. And like I said, I have always been saying -- said to folks, I'm a fierce partisan, but I think you can do that in a very civil way. I will fight for conservative principles day in and day out. I believe in this president's agenda.

utterances.speaker: CAVUTO
utterances.utterance: Well, you should have fought a little harder about that green shirt in the first going, you know?

utterances.speaker: CAVUTO
utterances.utterance: I know you auctioned it out.

utterances.speaker: SPICER
utterances.utterance: But you know what? Neil, Neil, that shirt -- that shirt went for 3,800 bucks.

utterances.speaker: CAVUTO
utterances.utterance: I heard. I heard.

utterances.speaker: SPICER
utterances.utterance: And we now split that between...

utterances.speaker: CAVUTO
utterances.utterance: I can't believe Hannity spent that much, but yes. Yes.

utterances.speaker: SPICER
utterances.utterance: Yes.

utterances.speaker: CAVUTO
utterances.utterance: I'm kidding. I'm kidding. You know, we were talking about this here.

utterances.speaker: SPICER
utterances.utterance: Hannity -- Hannity has been...

utterances.speaker: CAVUTO
utterances.utterance: Go ahead.

utterances.speaker: SPICER
utterances.utterance: He's been -- he wasn't too pleased. He is. He has said that friends don't let friends do that.

utterances.speaker: CAVUTO
utterances.utterance: Could you imagine if Hannity wore that on his show?

utterances.speaker: CAVUTO
utterances.utterance: Anyway, Sean Spicer. It's good to laugh at yourself, have fun. And he's having fun. Who knows? He could win it all, right? Anyway, let's get our read from "Your World" audio technician and author Dion Baia. We got Internet radio sensation Mike Gunzelman. They call him Gunz. We call him just whatever he wants us to call him.

utterances.speaker: MIKE GUNZELMAN, INTERNET RADIO HOST
utterances.utterance: There we go.

utterances.speaker: CAVUTO
utterances.utterance: And last, but not least, Kat on FOX Nation, Kat Timpf. Kat, I'm all for it. Have at it. Have fun. What do you think?

utterances.speaker: KATHERINE TIMPF, CONTRIBUTOR
utterances.utterance: Yes, I think that it's great to have fun. And it's so amazing to me that some people are upset about him being on the show.

utterances.speaker: CAVUTO
utterances.utterance: Well, do you remember, it was very controversial?

utterances.speaker: TIMPF
utterances.utterance: He worked for someone who I don't like. Therefore, he's not allowed to dance around. He's not allowed to have fun. He is laughing at himself. I think that that's very important.

utterances.speaker: CAVUTO
utterances.utterance: Absolutely.

utterances.speaker: TIMPF
utterances.utterance: I love to laugh at myself. You spend a lot less time crying if you're able to do that.

utterances.speaker: CAVUTO
utterances.utterance: I think you're right.

utterances.speaker: GUNZELMAN
utterances.utterance: I feel like Sean Spicer really remade his brand right now, that people are finding him as almost like a likable human being once again. He could have went away.

utterances.speaker: CAVUTO
utterances.utterance: Which he is. He is.

utterances.speaker: GUNZELMAN
utterances.utterance: Yes, exactly. And life -- everyone's like, oh, life is too short to take it serious all the time, which is true. People want people that can have fun, joke around with themselves. Nobody wants a stiff. Nobody wants somebody that's so overly defensive all the time.

utterances.speaker: TIMPF
utterances.utterance: I would love to be on the love so I could learn how to dance with my lower body. Like, I usually just do this.

utterances.speaker: TIMPF
utterances.utterance: And it's not a good look.

utterances.speaker: CAVUTO
utterances.utterance: I could see Dion in this getup here.

utterances.speaker: DION BAIA, AUDIO TECHNICIAN
utterances.utterance: You know me. I'm the first one to make fun of myself. I was doing years. They demanded stuff. It just made me look like a fool.

utterances.speaker: CAVUTO
utterances.utterance: Yes, you do. But look where you are now.

utterances.speaker: BAIA
utterances.utterance: Yes, exactly. It is really nice to be able to make fun of yourself or laugh at yourself, especially in a very family-friendly environment. Like he was saying, he has young children. That's really nice that he's able to have them sit in front of a TV.

utterances.speaker: CAVUTO
utterances.utterance: And that's a lot of pressure. And he freely admits, I can't dance.

utterances.speaker: BAIA
utterances.utterance: Prime-time television doesn't have family -- like that much family- friendly stuff. And it's good to be able to go on and drop the partisanship and just have fun.

utterances.speaker: CAVUTO
utterances.utterance: Have fun.

utterances.speaker: BAIA
utterances.utterance: And wear a green shirt.

utterances.speaker: GUNZELMAN
utterances.utterance: He looked like a dancing peacock, and it was perfect.

utterances.speaker: CAVUTO
utterances.utterance: What I found out is, there are conservatives who shouldn't be dancing and liberals who shouldn't be dancing. It's a bipartisan...

utterances.speaker: BAIA
utterances.utterance: Geraldo was on that show. That would be great if he wore a shirt like that.

utterances.speaker: BAIA
utterances.utterance: That thing is amazing. Look at that.

utterances.speaker: CAVUTO
utterances.utterance: And Tucker years ago.

utterances.speaker: BAIA
utterances.utterance: Tucker did it years ago, right.

utterances.speaker: TIMPF
utterances.utterance: I don't think I have ever been that happy.

utterances.speaker: CAVUTO
utterances.utterance: They have asked me. They have asked me. I'm thinking about it.

utterances.speaker: CAVUTO
utterances.utterance: ... dancing, doing all this stuff around me. One of the things he brought up -- and I don't know whether you agree with it, Kat -- is that the audience grows either with you or against you. Now, I don't know the show enough to know whether that's the case. How does that happen? I know you're not into the show.

utterances.speaker: TIMPF
utterances.utterance: I'm a die-hard fan.

utterances.speaker: CAVUTO
utterances.utterance: But you know what I'm saying, that it builds, he says? And there's something that's been building here. People who had doubts about him, like I said at the outset, where they were very leery of the political stuff and all, but that he's grown on people.

utterances.speaker: TIMPF
utterances.utterance: Good for him. I mean, you saw that photo that we keep bringing up where he's like...

utterances.speaker: CAVUTO
utterances.utterance: Right.

utterances.speaker: TIMPF
utterances.utterance: I mean, how do you look at that guy and go, uh, I hate that guy?

utterances.speaker: CAVUTO
utterances.utterance: Gunz is that way.

utterances.speaker: BAIA
utterances.utterance: He endears himself to a lot of people.

utterances.speaker: CAVUTO
utterances.utterance: And he laughs at himself.

utterances.speaker: BAIA
utterances.utterance: He's like almost the underdog. And people at home eating popcorn or whatever watching are like, that's nice. They like him to -- they want to see him go to the next round.

utterances.speaker: CAVUTO
utterances.utterance: Yes.

utterances.speaker: GUNZELMAN
utterances.utterance: Because he's not taking himself too seriously. People are starting to be like, you know what, that's cool. He's having fun. Like you said, like, there's so many bullies and people out there. The best thing you can do is just make fun yourself.

utterances.speaker: CAVUTO
utterances.utterance: What do you do with your career after this show, though? You know what I mean? I know there are a lot of people -- he's already a well-known entity.

utterances.speaker: TIMPF
utterances.utterance: Right.

utterances.speaker: CAVUTO
utterances.utterance: But where do you go after this?

utterances.speaker: BAIA
utterances.utterance: Well, some people can turn into something else.

utterances.speaker: CAVUTO
utterances.utterance: Really? Like what? What do you turn it into?

utterances.speaker: BAIA
utterances.utterance: Yes, he's going to become a professional dancer.

utterances.speaker: CAVUTO
utterances.utterance: He could advise politicians on dancing.

utterances.speaker: BAIA
utterances.utterance: How to dance and to be envoy for that show and then to also be like the foreign -- speaking relations to the show like that. When you go on, he will be your press secretary.

utterances.speaker: TIMPF
utterances.utterance: I think it's been good for him, though, because it has endeared more people to him. And I think it's harder to make fun of someone when they're already making fun of themselves first.

utterances.speaker: BAIA
utterances.utterance: Yes.

utterances.speaker: GUNZELMAN
utterances.utterance: ... to do is always embrace your fault and be like, yes, I'm fat. What's the big deal?

utterances.speaker: CAVUTO
utterances.utterance: Yes.

utterances.speaker: GUNZELMAN
utterances.utterance: Because then, if anybody goes after you, they can't.

utterances.speaker: CAVUTO
utterances.utterance: And he's funny about it and he's self-deprecating.

utterances.speaker: BAIA
utterances.utterance: It also shows the ludicrousy of the backlash on just a partisan level. He's having fun. People didn't want him on just because of the -- guilty by association.

utterances.speaker: CAVUTO
utterances.utterance: It was very biting. It was very biting. And I asked him about it. And he said yes, yes, and he just danced.

utterances.speaker: BAIA
utterances.utterance: Yes. And then people are like, hey, he's not that bad. He's funny. Look at the shirt he's wearing.

utterances.speaker: GUNZELMAN
utterances.utterance: Plus, who doesn't want to see more of that photo, right?

utterances.speaker: BAIA
utterances.utterance: I know.

utterances.speaker: CAVUTO
utterances.utterance: Guys, I want to thank you. I wanted to talk about this. Speaking of comedy and all that, Al Green, the congressman, he is very funny. People find that hard to believe. He's going to be joining me tomorrow on "Cavuto Live." This is one of the original guys who was saying, we got to impeach the president. Now the entire party is following him.
